text: hi my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh
here
the Internet's busiest music nerd lover
of all things music except music I don't
love and it's time for a review of the
new Blonde Redhead album Barragan indie
music vets Blonde Redhead they hail from
new york
they're our musical trio featuring
singer and multi-instrumentalist Kazuma
Kano
one of the most alluring voices in
underground music ever and then we have
the twins Amadeo and simone pace who
handle co songwriting as well as guitars
drums singing as well and together these
guys have penned some of the most
gorgeous sensual dreamy syrupy indie pop
and rock as well as noise rock of the
90s and 2000's and some a blonde
redheads biggest musical successes
aren't that far behind them we have
their o for album misery as a butterfly
2007's 23 and their last full-length LP
penny sparkle in 2010 while not
unanimously decided to be one of their
greatest albums by critics and fans I
enjoyed it though at the time I remember
quite a few people critiquing the sort
of change in pace that Blonde Redhead
took on this album embracing more
electronic elements maybe taking on a
little too many of the very trendy
chillwave sounds that were popular
around this year and even though Blonde
Redhead did work on a film score that
dropped in 2011 most hardcore fans were
most likely anticipating more this new
full-length of theirs Barragan and this
album is a very apparent sound and
direction change for Blonde Redhead it
is not quite as electronic as their last
full-length LP and it is nowhere near as
dense or as lush as their previous
albums either this time around Blonde
Redhead is sounding way more skeletal
and stripped back and eerie and sort of
intimate - I think Blonde Redhead does a
good job of maintaining a lot of their
usual characteristics but they deliver
them in a much darker and simpler and
more
mangle way however I will not beat
around the bush when it comes to my
opinion of this record I feel like it is
a bit of a letdown there are some
musical highlights on these standard 10
tracks song listing on this record and
for sure this sound change sounds really
exciting in concept in blueprint but
there are some incredibly lacking songs
on this record as well
it seems like in the midst of this less
is more ideal that Blonde Redhead
presents there are some songs here that
present much too little like with the
song cat on a tin roof a very loosely
and shyly played piece of vintage pop
music and it doesn't even sound like
Blonde Redhead wrote this song it's
almost as if they're just doing it off
the top of their heads because the
performance of this song doesn't really
have that much purpose to it it's almost
as if the band is just kind of playing
to kill time like they're waiting for
something to happen I was thinking it's
almost as if they're in the middle of
soundcheck or something which was
something that to me felt sort of
confirmed because as soon as kazoos
first sung verse is over it's almost as
if she says like something aside into
the microphone to the sound engineer or
something almost as if they're just
getting levels on this track and this is
just a spare instrumental or b-side that
they just tossed onto the record even
though the performance is borderline
horrendous this song is like the epitome
have not given a it's almost as if
they just put it on this record because
there's a 10 track song requirement or
something and then there's the 9 minute
mind to be had which feels like it was
just put into the track listening to
fulfil a time requirement the song is a
very coherent sort of tightly played jam
has kind of a krautrock esque steady
repetitive groove to it but the very
faint and shy progressions of the
instrumentation on this song in no way
justify the length and convincing things
and then there's the three minutes or so
of filler directly after the two minutes
of decent songwriting on the song
defeatist anthem it is a very coherent
and pleasant song up until the point
where it ends it has a beautiful
haunting melody that kind of remind
me of a early Portishead or something
like that but as soon as this music dies
down it goes to silence and the band
just presents one disjointed
musical interlude after another
essentially killing time up until the
track reaches the six-minute mark and
there's also tracks on here like
dripping which to me musically
stylistically are absolutely faceless
and to me Blonde Redhead is a band that
has been very much not faceless very
much bold very much chock full of
personality but this track to me kind of
sounds like your average jangly pretend
shoegaze reverb rock underground
soundcloud band trying to do a cover of
Daft Punk's get lucky then there's seven
to the uninspiring lis redundant closing
track of this LP which starts off really
promising but it's by the end of the
song that I realized that it's pretty
much nearly the same guitar part over
and over and over as well as the same
beat Kazu doesn't really build her
vocals up that significantly over the
course of the track now most of my
favorite tracks on this record are
disappointingly short but they are still
highlights nonetheless there is the
title and opening track on this LP which
is a little instrumental feature some
woodwinds some acoustic guitar it's
gorgeous
it's enchanting would have worked really
well in like a Led Zeppelin album or
something and this track gives way
directly to one of the best songs on
this entire record
lady n the track with an incredibly slow
smoky sensual sound this is the kind of
sensuality that I expect from and love
to hear from Blonde Redhead this song to
me just feels like 1930s jazz club
spotlight just loads of cigarette smoke
in the air red dress red curtains it's
just beautiful there's a great beat
stellar chorus I love the melody on this
track the Weeping guitars and strings
it's a wonderful song it's just
heartbreaking that there are so many
tracks following this song that are
absolutely underwhelming there are some
other saving graces in the middle
this tracklisting - in my opinion like
the song no more honey the song is a
little rough around the edges but it has
a beautiful guitar melody some really
interesting loud soft dynamics going on
with the choruses and the verses and
with the really strange effects on the
vocals and the weird buzzing guitars
layered over the chorus I think this
song is the closest that Blonde Redhead
comes to it's shoegazing roots on this
record and the song the one I love is a
really sparse strange and haunting
acoustic ballad that features a rush of
drums and harpsichord over the chorus
again they're kind of playing with that
loud soft dynamic over the verses and
the choruses I love how kazoos voice on
this song is so still and so stone-faced
it's just kind of haunting and
frightening and the lyrics she presents
on this track as well are absolutely
depressing there are some standout songs
on this record I love the aesthetic that
blonde redhead is shooting for on this
LP and again I enjoy the usual
characteristics that you find in a
Blonde Redhead record but this album is
incredibly lacking in song writing
sometimes presenting songs that are just
absolutely drab and boring whether that
be because of the the melodies or the
performances and then again there are
tracks like cat on tin roof which
there's really just no explanation for
if there's one thing that's strange and
interesting about this album is that it
really runs the gamut of just really
top-notch stellar instrumentally
methodical and very well put together in
detailed songs and tracks that are like
getting a cold lump of mashed potatoes
thrown into your lunch tray in a
cafeteria housed inside of a compound
where you now live because you've given
your life over to a cult yeah it's like
it's that bad I'm feeling a strong five
to a light six on this LP transition if
you've given this album a listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think I
should review next let me know and
you're the best subscribe have a nice

Anthony Fantana Blonde Redhead forever
